general.title: Amino acids in pollen of Osmia bicornis larval provisions 2017-2018
general.abstract: Biodiversity loss, often found in intensively managed agricultural landscapes, correlates with reduced ecosystem functioning, e.g. insect pollination and altered floral resource diversity, abundance and composition. How this affects bee foraging and larval diets in solitary wild bees is largely unclear. To better understand impacts of land-use intensification on wild bee-plant interactions, we investigated communities of trap nesting solitary bees, their pollen foraging and the nutritional quality of larval food composed in grasslands along a land-use intensity gradient across three bioregions (Swabian Alb, Hainich- Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in Germany.

studyDesign.detailedDescriptionOfStudyDesign:
Number of time based repetitions (information from the old BExIS schema): 2To assess how land-use induced differences in the diversity and composition of plant species used for pollen collection by Osmia bicornis affected the nutritional composition of larval pollen provisions, we analyzed the composition of amino acids in pollen provisions of O. bicornis trap nests at 15 plots (VIP plots).
(Note: former name of the section was measurements/theory)

measurements.samplingDesign:
Ion exchange chromatography (IEC)
(Note: former name of the section was measurements/type)
measurements.equipment:
Instruments: Trap nests: - Each trap nest contained a plastic tube (sewer pipes (length 110-120 cm); cut smaller pieces with 20 cm length) with 60-80 hollow reed sticks (length ~ 20 cm, width 4-12 mm). - Trap nest protection (wire mesh; mesh width (min 1.3-1.5 mm)). - Reed sticks with closed entrances were removed from plastic tubes, replaced with new reed sticks, and then directly and gently (temperature protection!) transported to the lab
Calibration: - Sterile forceps - Ion exchange chromatography (IEC) with high-pressure PEEK column and autosampler
Procedure: Total protein content was calculated as the sum of all amino acids
